children.subject:
Following what the comment said, it is therefore a very high probability that graduating early is a terrible idea, and to expound on the reasons, primarily that the value of "having options" is very underestimated - 

1. In state tuition is completely insignificant to the housing pricing in MV/SV ($3500/month for a single apartment, is a multiple worse than e.g. having a Wall Street apartment). For an incoming engineer, this is already half of post-tax salary; you barely save anything in your first years of work, and income can only gradually increase overtime by locking yourself in the same company for many years (because of the structure of bonus, stock options, etc.)

2. You biologically and mentally change throughout your years, learning and finding A is boring, B is too hard, C is too easy, D isn't actually what the media reports, etc. - while some amount of focus is valuable, something as hoop-jumping as "graduating early" only for the sake of saving money (and you don't even save much anyways) isn't a worthy cause

3. Planning to graduate early implies you'll just take all the requirements and not do anything you enjoy - we've been through K-12 in a 7-3, studying boring things, and in a job, we go 9-5 doing sometimes boring work; college is one of the only times that we're allowed to take a break from that and cherish what we like, and can't be underestimated
Are you in state or out of state?

history.content:
Do it if you know that you are definitely going for a job after college AND you already know what specific field you are interested working in AND money is very important to you. If you want to go to grad school, you need to have a good relationship with professor + research, so the more time you put into it, the better.

On a personal note, I am only in my sophomore year, and my personal/academic interests are way different than what they were coming into freshman year. My suggestion is to have an open mind; college will probably be the only time when you can get away with it :)

Feel free to schedule an appointment with one of us if you wish to discuss with an adviser https://berkeleycs.youcanbook.me/  https://berkeleyeecs.youcanbook.me/

I can graduate in 2 years if I want. I'm a freshman. Should I do it? Is it worth saving money vs learning more for 1-2 extra years?

I know it's subjective, but what would YOU, as someone older and more experienced than me, recommend?
history.subject: Should I graduate in 2 years?

history.content: I can graduate in 2 years if I want. I'm a freshman. Should I do it? Is it worth saving money vs learning more for 1-2 extra years?
